body: @ctubbsii thoughts?

@kubina This issue seems very vague, and sounds a bit more like something a general purpose Java profiler tool would be for, rather than something specific to Accumulo. Do you have a specific, actionable step in mind that an Accumulo developer who works on this issue could begin working on that is in scope of Accumulo? If there's not something specific for somebody to work on for this, this ticket seems likely to be passed over and just sit here idle for a long time.

I don't think it's a good idea to incorporate scanning into the web interface of the monitor. This raises a bunch of concerns about security, especially authentication. The monitor is also supposed to be a limited status monitoring service, not a triage service. Adding scan features to the monitor would expand its scope significantly, and I think it's better to keep its scope limited.

Prior to 2.0, we did have the ability to scan via the monitor, because we had an embedded shell inside the monitor when it was running with SSL/TLS. We stripped it out, to simplify the service. It was fraught with security concerns anyway, so it's probably best that it was stripped out.

> I don't think it's a good idea to incorporate scanning into the web interface of the monitor. This raises a bunch of concerns about security, especially authentication.

What concerns of authentication?  

> The monitor is also supposed to be a limited status monitoring service, not a triage service.

I don't see a difference. I think Admins would like the ability to scan the metadata table.

> > I don't think it's a good idea to incorporate scanning into the web interface of the monitor. This raises a bunch of concerns about security, especially authentication.
> 
> What concerns authentication?

The monitor runs as the system user. It will be able to scan with system-level permissions. If we were to change this, we would have to create something like we had with the embedded shell where we track sessions and allow users to authenticate as themselves. User authentication and session management dramatically increases the scope and complexity of the monitor.

Beyond the authentication bits, one of our driving principles for the monitor is that it never exposes user data. We even hash tablet information, so we don't expose end rows and other potentially sensitive user data that leaks into the metadata table, and potentially out to the monitor, which is designed to run on the perimeter of the cluster. Having scan features baked in to the monitor that brings this data back to a web user completely undermines this security principle.

> 
> > The monitor is also supposed to be a limited status monitoring service, not a triage service.
> 
> I don't see a difference. I think Admins would like the ability to scan the metadata table.

The difference is night and day. The shell provides a mechanism for simple query, troubleshooting, and management, in an authenticated, local process. The monitor runs as a service to support multiple simultaneous users (it is a web service, after all), with basic "what is Accumulo doing right now" kind of information. There's even the opinion (although I haven't heard it expressed recently) by some of us that the monitor is already doing too much, and it's possible it is teaching users, to rely on it for monitoring their clusters instead of deploying a proper monitoring infrastructure.

Admins want many things, but we can't always provide everything they want in the specific way they want it. We need to draw the line somewhere to keep Accumulo from dying of scope creep and complexity.

> The shell provides a mechanism for simple query, troubleshooting, and management, in an authenticated, local process.

I was speaking with an Admin and they only use root on the shell, defeating the whole purpose of multiple users.  I guess its just easier for their setup.

@jzgithub1 This isn't quite right. This change confirms that the StackOverflow description of how to use the DistributedCache correctly actually works as described. However, what we really need, is to modify our (non-test) code to use the DistributedCache correctly, now that we have confirmed that the description on StackOverflow is correct.

Thanks for the feedback.  It seemed to me that our implementation is OK.  We are not using that "URI with the pound sign with an alias string"  technique they use on Stack Overflow.  Otherwise I see the file our code pulls from the cache just fine in the test directory whether the URI alias or expected file name is used.  

I will revisit the issue and modify the non-test code to use the StackOverflow technique since this is what you want.

> Thanks for the feedback. It seemed to me that our implementation is OK. We are not using that "URI with the pound sign with an alias string" technique they use on Stack Overflow. Otherwise I see the file our code pulls from the cache just fine in the test directory whether the URI alias or expected file name is used.

The problem is that our code appears to be using the DistributedCache, but it's not actually using it. That's a bug in our code. We are using it incorrectly. Instead of reading the file stored in the cache, we're merely confirming that the file at the URI was requested to be put in the cache... and then we're promptly ignoring the cached copy and instead reading the file directly from HDFS anyway.

The correct usage is the technique you verified works from StackOverflow. Step 1 was to verify that the StackOverflow technique worked... which you did, and that was great. Step 2 is to actually fix our broken usage. :smiley_cat:
OK.  I understand what is going on now.
I think we are in agreement that baking this into the Monitor isn't the best place... leaving open for now in case others have ideas.

mvn clean verify -Dit.test=SplitIT,TabletIT -Dtest=foo -Dspotbugs.skip

I ran some of your changes locally and saw 
[ERROR] testWriteSpeed(org.apache.accumulo.test.functional.DurabilityIT)  Time elapsed: 125.991 s  <<< ERROR!
org.junit.runners.model.TestTimedOutException: test timed out after 120000 milliseconds

This probably not be related to your change as we have a few flaky tests and this is one of them.

@milleruntime I believe that this test is not run by default.  Jeff M. found that this test can fail on the 2nd or 3rd test - comparing sync time and flush time.  Depending on the hardware the times can be different than expected. He may be putting a ticket in.

> @milleruntime or @ctubbsii , for the tests that are timing out we can recommend in docs to add a timeout.factor to the mvn verify for standalone tests or I can update the specific tests and up the defaulttimeout in the tests. Which do you prefer?

Letting developers know of the timeout.factor isn't a bad idea. If they are doing development on weaker machines than what might be run on a server, they will almost certainly need to use it occasionally.

> I ran some of your changes locally and saw
> [ERROR] testWriteSpeed(org.apache.accumulo.test.functional.DurabilityIT) Time elapsed: 125.991 s <<< ERROR!
> org.junit.runners.model.TestTimedOutException: test timed out after 120000 milliseconds
> 
> This probably not be related to your change as we have a few flaky tests and this is one of them.

@milleruntime Yeah, I have had several issues regarding this test in particular. Generally not with the timeouts though but with the assertTrue statements being false. Sometimes sync was faster than flush, sometimes it was flush faster than log. No real consistent results from my testing but it was either of these two failing. 

I did notice that the older hardware we have here did run it successfully multiple times but our newer machines were the ones being inconsistent. Should this be a separate issue?  I have tried to find  workarounds for it but no real luck. Only thing that seemed to get more consistent results  was returning the first attempt (attempts[0]) rather than the median (attempts[2]) one in the writeSome function. https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/master/test/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/test/functional/DurabilityIT.java#L241 
That's probably not a viable solution for this test though.

Feel free to try different things. 

This test has been a thorn for some time so it would be good to fix it up.   I opened a separate ticket for DurabilityIT: https://github.com/apache/accumulo/issues/1159

Another option is to create a performance test in accumulo-testing for it, and remove it from here.

https://github.com/apache/accumulo-testing#performance-test

It might make sense to generalize this and avoid tablet assignment and balancing if the number of tablet servers is less than desired.  This would handle a case where the master is currently running and 90% of the tservers die.

Below is the code that does assignment.

https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/rel/1.9.3/server/master/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/master/TabletGroupWatcher.java#L930

Below is the code that does balancing.

https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/rel/1.9.3/server/master/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/master/Master.java#L1078

Clarification of the desired design:

On job setup (by user):
1. User inputs filename
2. We append mnemonic and create URI
3. We save URI in our config property
4. We tell distributed cache to store URI

On job run (by framework/us):
1. We read our URI from our config property
2. We check to see if we can read file with the mnemonic
3.   if no, we log a warning, and then use URI to read from HDFS directly

All ITs pass.

Tested user experience with enabling debug on/off in the shell, since that feature was deprecated and disabled in this PR. User must edit log4j.properties (or their logback, or other slf4j implementation's, config file) and restart the shell. It's definitely less convenient than dynamically changing the log level in code when issuing "debug on" command in the shell. However, dropping this is the only way we can break our tight coupling with log4j, and allow users to use their preferred logging framework (such as logback). This also sets us up to be able to upgrade to log4j2 (once the deprecated mapreduce APIs are dropped), since log4j1.2 that we're using hasn't been maintained in 7 years.

I have created two issues #1133 and #1134 that are related and may be the first steps towards addressing some of this ticket.  
While those issues will not resolve this issue - it seems to me that they can form a cleaner baseline for moving forward.  I expect that, as this issue evolves, "sub-issues" will be created to address specific items - so for now, I'm thinking this issue is capturing things at an "epic" level rather that a pure task.

Also pushed up the IteratorEnvIT test change.  The Asserts were failing on the standalone because junit is not deployed with accumulo.   A RuntimeException was the only exception that did not require a "throws" or change to the implemented interface.

I think you're suggesting that we stop printing deprecated properties that aren't set? If so, I think that could be a good idea, but I can also see it being useful to somebody debugging to explicitly see in the logs that the property wasn't set. I don't have a strong opinion either way.

Right, we don't want to break behavior of the property until after it is documented as deprecated, and we are ready to remove it. Right now, it's sufficient to document it as deprecated.
